head.title: Bottom-Line Thinking Won't Save Our Climate; Clean Air Tax Credit

hedline.hl1: Bottom-Line Thinking Won't Save Our Climate; Clean Air Tax Credit

block.p: The Science Times article on global warming (Nov. 14) summarizes concerns about warming resulting from carbon dioxide emissions into the atmosphere. About one-third of those emissions come from burning fossil fuels for electric power.
A substantial reduction in carbon dioxide emissions to the atmosphere may be achieved by providing financial incentives for the replacement or displacement of polluting power by nonpolluting power.

I propose that a clean air tax credit of, say, 15 percent, be provided for any new power plant that emits no carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. The clean air tax credit would be prorated downward, depending upon the carbon dioxide emission of the power generation process relative to coal. Coal generates approximately two pounds of carbon dioxide per kilowatt-hour produced. Thus, a technology that causes no carbon dioxide emission (solar, hydro, most geothermal sources) would get full credit. Those that emit some carbon dioxide (natural gas) would be entitled to a partial tax credit. TSVI MEIDAV Oakland, Calif., Nov. 17, 1989
